step.context: \text{Which of the following must be true}\\ \text{for }f(x)\text{ to be strictly decreasing?}
step.reason: \text{A strictly decreasing function is always}\\ \text{decreasing. Which means, }f'(x)\neq 0 \text{ anywhere.}\\ \text{Hence the condition }\frac{d}{dx}f(x)\lt 0.

step.context: \text{Does the table below correctly capture}\\ \text{the relative values of }\cos x\text{ and }-100\cdot x^{99}?
step.tex: \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} x & \cos x & -100\cdot x^{99} \\ \hline (0,1) & \gt 0 & \lt 0 \\ \left(\frac\pi{2},\pi\right) &\lt 0, \gt -1 & \lt -100\implies\lt -1\\ \left(0,\frac\pi{2}\right) & \gt 0 & \lt 0 \\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ \text{As, }\cos x\nless -100x^{99}\text{ in any of the given}\\ \text{intervals, therefore f(x) cannot be strictly}\\ \text{decreasing in any of them.}
step.reason: \text{The trickiest interval is }\left(\frac\pi{2},\pi\right). \text{Remember, }\frac\pi{2}\gt 1.\\ \text{ And therefore, }\frac\pi{2}\lt x\lt \pi\implies x^{99}\gt 1\\ \implies -100x^{99}\lt -100\implies -100x^{99}\lt -1\lt \cos x.
